title: RS21342
content: The diversity visa lottery encourages legal immigration from countries other than major sending countries to the US. It was added to the Immigration and Nationality Act in 1990 to promote new and varied migration. The current lottery started in FY1995 after temporary lotteries. The diversity visa lottery, added to the Immigration and Nationality Act in 1990, aims to stimulate new immigration by offering 55,000 visas annually to countries with lower immigrant admissions in the previous five years. The United States Citizenship and Immigration Services Bureau allocates visas based on a specific formula. The Diversity Visa Lottery provides 55,000 visas annually to countries with lower immigrant admissions in the previous five years. Visas are allocated based on a formula that considers the relative populations of six geographic regions, with a limit of 3,850 visas per country and Northern Ireland treated separately. The Diversity Visa Lottery allocates 55,000 visas annually based on regional populations, with a 7% limit per country and Northern Ireland treated separately. Recipients become legal permanent residents of the United States, and the Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act temporarily reduces the annual visa ceiling by up to 5,000 visas. The Diversity Visa Lottery allocates 55,000 visas annually based on regional populations, with recipients becoming legal permanent residents of the United States. The Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act temporarily reduces the annual visa ceiling by up to 5,000 visas to offset immigrant visa numbers for certain unsuccessful asylum seekers. In FY1999, the diversity visa ceiling became 50,000 to offset immigrant visa numbers for unsuccessful asylum seekers from certain countries.
